Literature Review: Elastic thermobarometry has emerged as a powerful technique in metamorphic petrology, providing valuable insights into the pressure-temperature (P-T) conditions of mineral formation and subsequent exhumation. This method relies on the principle that inclusions trapped within host minerals experience differential strains due to contrasting compressibilities and thermal expansivities during exhumation and cooling. These strains can be measured and used to reconstruct the P-T conditions of inclusion entrapment, offering a unique window into the metamorphic history of rocks.The foundation of elastic thermobarometry lies in the pioneering work of Rosenfeld and Chase (1961), who first proposed the concept of using mineral inclusions as indicators of metamorphic conditions. However, it was not until the development of advanced analytical techniques, particularly Raman spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction, that the full potential of this method could be realized. Angel et al. (2014) provided a comprehensive review of the theoretical framework and practical applications of elastic thermobarometry, establishing it as a robust tool for petrologists.One of the key advantages of elastic thermobarometry is its ability to provide in situ measurements of inclusion strains. Raman spectroscopy has proven particularly useful in this regard, as demonstrated by Kohn (2014), who showed how Raman shift could be used to quantify pressures in quartz inclusions within garnet hosts. This non-destructive technique allows for the preservation of textural relationships and the potential for multiple analyses on a single sample.The accuracy of elastic thermobarometry relies heavily on the knowledge of mineral equations of state and elastic properties. Significant progress has been made in this area, with studies such as Angel et al. (2017) providing refined equations of state for common inclusion-host mineral pairs. These improvements have enhanced the precision of P-T estimates derived from elastic thermobarometry.However, the application of elastic thermobarometry is not without challenges. Factors such as inclusion shape, proximity to surfaces, and crystal-axis anisotropy can significantly affect strain measurements and subsequent P-T calculations. Mazzucchelli et al. (2018) addressed these issues through detailed modeling and experiments, providing important corrections that have improved the accuracy of elastic thermobarometers, particularly for the commonly used quartz-in-garnet system.Recent research has expanded the scope of elastic thermobarometry beyond simple P-T determinations. For instance, Moulas et al. (2020) explored how elastic thermobarometry could be used to investigate the conditions of crystal growth and reaction overstepping. This work has opened up new avenues for understanding the kinetics of metamorphic reactions and the role of disequilibrium in mineral formation.The influence of differential stresses on inclusion-host systems has also been a subject of recent investigation. Bonazzi et al. (2019) demonstrated how elastic thermobarometry could be used to estimate the magnitudes of differential stresses experienced by rocks during metamorphism, providing valuable information about tectonic processes.An important consideration in the application of elastic thermobarometry is the potential for inelastic resetting of inclusion and host strains. Zhong et al. (2020) investigated the effects of plastic deformation on quartz inclusions in garnet, showing that under certain conditions, the original entrapment conditions may be partially or completely overprinted. This work highlights the need for careful interpretation of elastic thermobarometry data, particularly in high-grade metamorphic rocks.Despite these challenges, the field of elastic thermobarometry continues to evolve and expand. Researchers are now exploring the potential for developing new thermobarometers for lower-symmetry minerals, which could greatly extend the applicability of this technique. For example, Alvaro et al. (2020) proposed a new elastic thermobarometer based on rutile inclusions in garnet, demonstrating the potential for applying this method to a wider range of mineral assemblages.In conclusion, elastic thermobarometry has revolutionized our ability to reconstruct metamorphic P-T paths and understand the tectonic processes that shape the Earth's crust. While challenges remain, ongoing research continues to refine and expand this technique, promising even greater insights into the complex world of metamorphic petrology in the future.
